sp.p: Why, I can make allowances, Mr. Fancourt; I remember myſelf, when I was High Sheriff for the county, I once paſſed an acqaintance, but I made him an apology; and, Sir, I ſhall expect an apology from my Lord, for not returning my bow, before I advance the thouſand pounds. A thouſand pounds is money, Mr. Fancourt.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p:
It is—it is, Sir, and the man who will not make a bow for a thouſand pounds, ought never to poſſeſs a thouſand pence (laughs aſide). I will go, Sir, and bring his Lordſhip here (going). He dines to-day at the Dutcheſs's in his own ſquare; but I'll engage to bring him away in ſpite of wit, and beauty, and champaigne.
I'll be a match for thee yet, old Taffy! (aſide).

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: I wiſh my Lord wou'd invite me to dine at a Dutcheſs's. I never did dine with a Dutcheſs. It muſt be very delightful! I ſhould go back to Glamorganſhire, and be able to amuſe my neighbours with all her Grace's bons mots, and repeat her Grace's toaſts; I would hold my aſs-ſkin ſlily under the table, and pencil down her good things. 'Tis all the faſhion now. Many a man gets a dinner by being known to write down the wit of his hoſt or hoſteſs; tho', after long watching, he frequently brings away empty tablets. Exit.

div.stage: GEORGINA enters laughing audibly, followed by JENNY.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Aye, Miſs, you may laugh, but for my part, I doesn't ſee any thing in your alablaſter ſtatutes—all of one colour, like a duck's egg. Give me a fine large picture, with robes of red, and blue, and rich damaſk cartains.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Your taſte is excellent! (continuing to laugh).

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: But if you talk of ſtatuary, go to Mrs. Silvertip's.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Who is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Why, a lady who makes the fineſt ſtatutes in the world, all in wax. There are generals,— and ſailors — and princeſſes — and dukes—and old women, more natural than life. Now if I can raiſe her curioſity to go there, Jack's buſineſs is done (aſide).

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Dear Jenny, how can I ſee them?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Why, by going to her Exhibition on Fiſh-ſtreet-hill.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Fiſh-ſtreet-hill—where is that?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Hang me if I know (aſide). O! Miſs, every body knows where that is. 'Tis juſt by Groſvenor Square.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: I wonder if ſhe wou'd teach me her art?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Yes, to be ſure ſhe wou'd. All arts are to be learnt by thoſe who have money, except the art of being happy.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Then the firſt uſe I would make of it, ſhould be to imitate the features of Mr. Conway in wax. I then ſhou'd be able to look at him without bluſhing, and even talk to him without his being a bit the wiſer.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Mr. Conway, indeed! (aſide, petulantly).

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: O dear! yes I will, I will learn the art. I know his countenance ſo well, that I ſhou'd be able to copy it without ever ſeeing him more. And yet there is one look, which no art can imitate! (tenderly).

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Devil take him! (aſide). Well, Miſs, I'll carry you there to-morrow. But Sir Robert muſt not know it.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: O not for the world! I will go— I will go—I will go. Runs off.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Yes, ſo you ſhall; but Mr. Conway ſhall never be the better for it. You have a large fortune, my dear, and are handſome; my brother is handſome, and has no fortune—the beſt reaſon for to bring you together.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Where is my daughter?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Juſt gone to her dreſſing-room, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Then I'll go and hear her on the harp a little. She has a ſweet finger; aye— and ſhe is a ſweet girl; but my heart has a thouſand aches about her, and dearly as I love her, I am ready ſometimes to exclaim with the old ſong, "I wonder any man alive, would ever have a daughter."

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: O! you old— if you'd had wit enough for to have put a proper value on my charms, I would have taken every care about your daughter off your hands;—but I'll be revenged for all your tricks! here I have been ſpending anxious days, and ſleepleſs nights, for two years;—making up the ſmarteſt caps of waſh'd gauze and dyed ribbons;—buying new braids of hair, of a nice nut brown—and all without being able to touch the old gooſe, any more than if his heart was made of leather. But I'll match you! ſince you will not make me your wife, I'll give your daughter a huſband; and if you ſhould die of the mortification, I know where to find a place to dance on. Exit.

div.head: SCENE IV.—ASGILL's Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Aſgill.
sp.p:
O! 'tis in vain! never, Conway, will I ſue for compaſſion from a proud beauty, who
treated me with haughtineſs, even when ſhe believed me heir to proſperity.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Pride and lovelineſs ought to go together. I diſlike the vulgar railing againſt the haughtineſs of conſcious beauty. She, who over values herſelf, will never ſink too low; and the lady of whom we ſpeak, perhaps loves you.

sp.speaker: Aſgill.
sp.p: For that very reaſon, I will not again appear before her. I am too proud to raiſe a conflict in her boſom between her pride, and her tenderneſs, and to owe at length, perhaps, to her compaſſion, the acceptance to which her love would never have acceded.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: You are very nice. If my heart were not pre-occupied, and ſo fine a woman had an inclination to make me maſter of herſelf and fortune, I would not quarrel with her about the motive; I wou'd thank the pretty creature, and give her all the love I could.

sp.speaker: Aſgill.
sp.p: Yes; but you are a man of fortune. By this time, I ſuppoſe, people begin to talk of my diſtreſs'd ſtate.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: I have heard it mentioned.

sp.speaker: Aſgill.
sp.p: What has been ſaid?

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: A lady obſerved, that it was pity a man ſo handſome ſhou'd be ſunk ſo low; and her huſband ſaid he was ſorry, becauſe you were ſuch a good kind of young man.

sp.speaker: Aſgill
sp.p:
(with contempt). Good kind of young man! I am ſorry I have incurr'd ſuch an approbation. (Conway ſeems ſurpriſed) No, no, do not imagine (ſmiling) that I wiſh for the reputation of a bad heart. But the term, "Good kind of young man," in our days, is ſo
applied, that I deſire not to be honoured with it. An idle fellow, who hangs looſe on ſociety, without merit or avocation, or one who corrupts the ſiſter of his friend, or runs away with his daughter, or does all thoſe things which mankind ought to execrate, is ſaid, in excuſe, to be a good kind of young man. In ſhort, good kind of young man, in the preſent acceptance, may very fairly be tranſlated ſcoundrel.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Sir, here is the perſon you ordered from Tower-hill. Slopſeller, I think he calls himſelf. Exit.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Slopſeller! How do you tranſlate that? Apothecary, I ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: Aſgill.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! No, I aſſure you. A Tower-hill ſlopſeller does not deal in emulſions and ſyrups, he—but you muſt excuſe my telling you what he deals in. (growing grave) My dear Conway, adieu! Often think of me, and ſpeak of me as I deſerve; but be ſure you never ſuffer people to call me a good kind of young man.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Aſgill, though there is ſome pleaſantry in your manner, there is alſo a ſeriouſneſs which ſhocks me. What are you going to do?

sp.speaker: Aſgill.
sp.p: What I ought to do. What, do you imagine I intend to ſtay at home, to parade Bond-ſtreet, and make the circle of Piccadilly, Saint James's-ſtreet, and Pall-mall? No, no, my burning brain cannot be cooled by ſuch expedients; 'tis only the powerful voice of my country can regulate its diſtraction—Aſk no queſtions—my reſolution is fixed—Farewell!

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: What! and is the frenzy of your brain regulated by the hope of ſerving your country? Do all your private woes ſink before that powerful principle! O! glorious effect of patriotic love! Every ſelfiſh feeling vaniſhes—to tear myſelf from you becomes a DUTY. I go—deſpiſe not this weakneſs—I venerate, I pity you! Exit.

sp.speaker: Aſgill.
sp.p: Friend of my heart! He goes in tears! Oh! the drops which manly friendſhip forces from the eye, are more precious than thoſe collected in the groves of rich Arabia— They ſink into my heart—they cheriſh it!— Now come in, Sir. Enter a Man, with a bundle. Have you brought what I ordered?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes; here are the things, Sir. (opens the bundle)

sp.speaker: Aſgill.
sp.p: This, then, is the complete dreſs of an Engliſh ſailor?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Complete! (opening and diſplaying it)

sp.speaker: Aſgill.
sp.p: O! the ſight of it warms my heart! In this dreſs what heroes have bled—what gallant acts have been atchieved! Thoſe who have worn it, have given England all her glory—have given her the boundleſs empire of the ocean.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, it was your Raleighs, and your Drakes, and your Boſcawens who did all that.

sp.speaker: Aſgill.
sp.p:
O! whilſt our grateful retroſpection twines laurels around the heroes of departed days, let us not forget what is due to thoſe of our own! Let us look with gratitude towards a HOWE, and hang, with tributary tears, over
the names of MONTAGUE, HARVEY, and HUTT!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Ah! the three laſt are gone.

sp.speaker: Aſgill.
sp.p: But ſome remain. There only wants occaſion, and other Montagues, and other Harveys will ſtart out like meteors, and glide along the Britiſh ſky, blazing in glory!

div.stage: (Goes out, preſſing the bundle to him.)

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Gad! he's a fine fellow, and will make a noble ſailor; but our fleets, thank heaven, are full of ſuch. Exit.

sp.speaker: Aſgill.
sp.p: There are ſtill two bills unpaid—go and diſcharge them. That purſe contains ſufficient. Exit Servant. Now, all my debts paid, and a few guineas in my pocket, I quit my country; but I quit her, to ſerve her! O! may the boundleſs bleſſings of heaven deſcend upon her; may my arm contribute to reſtore peace to her; and may GLORY and MONARCHY be hers, till time ſhall be no more! Exit.

div.head: SCENE I.—Lady HORATIA's Drawing-room.
div.stage: She enters with rapidity and diſorder, then turns, and ſpeaks.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: Yes—order the horſes inſtantly—and yet —no—I ſhall not want them— Go to his uncle in the city! How ſtrange that will be! But can I heſitate on decorums, when EXISTENCE is at ſtake? Can I ſuffer Sidney Aſgill to believe that Georgina's fooleries are my ſentiments? Can I ſuffer another to have the tranſport of lifting him from poverty, whilſt I am deſpiſed! The thought breaks my heart-ſtrings! Ah! Mr. Conway!

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: I flew the moment I received your commands.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: My commands! Sir, I only ſent to aſk—it was only with an intention to — (much confuſed.)

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Speak, Lady Horatia. (a pauſe) Do me the honour to repoſe confidence in me.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I believe I can— I believe I ought—but ſhame weighs down my very ſoul. In one moment what will you think of me?

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: What I have always thought, that you are one of the firſt of your ſex.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia
sp.p: (walks a little way in extreme agitation, then returns). I muſt ſpeak, for the conflict is too great for me to endure. You are the friend of Aſgill—the friend of his youth—the choſen of his heart. (he bows) — Permit me to then to aſk, even though your anſwer ſhou'd be a breach of confidence, did you ever hear him mention any other lady as one —as one—with whom he wiſhed to unite his fate?

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: O never! You are the object of his adoration.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: (with quickneſs) Then find him out—purſue him! What have I ſaid? My ſoul ſhrinks at the ſound of the words I have uttered.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Would my Aſgill's ears could have received them! Go on, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia,
sp.p: Go on! Alas! need I add another ſentence! You ſee that—humble me not too far—I am proud—Had Aſgill continued the heir of ſplendid poſſeſſions, perhaps my pride and coldneſs would never have abated; but he is poor; he is undone!

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Peerleſs woman!

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: My fortune is his—my heart —my ſoul!

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: O! ſuffer me to kneel for him! For him I thank you, adorable, tranſcendent woman!

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p:
I feel your kindneſs in endeavouring to abate my confuſion. The ſtep I have taken I ſhou'd yeſterday have thought leſs eaſy than to die. Permit me to leave you, nor dare to think (with reſumed dignity) that, becauſe my paſſion is ſtrong, my conduct ſhall be
weak! My reputation is in your hands— preſerve it as you wou'd your own life and honour. Exit.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: I accept the glorious depoſit, and I will deſerve the truſt. What grace can dignity of ſoul beſtow! The very conduct which from a vulgar mind would diſguſt, from ſuch elegance and virtue becomes faſcinating. Now, Aſgill, I will dare to ſeek thee; and I will pour ſuch tranſport on thy heart, as ſhall make thee confeſs, the hour of thy poverty the moſt bleſſed of thy life. Exit.

div.head: SCENE II—Sir ROBERT FLOYER's Library.
div.stage: Enter Sir ROBERT in a hurry, followed by a Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Bring up his lordſhip and Mr. Fancourt directly—fly down—never keep a lord in waiting. Exit Servant. (Sits.) No, I won't receive his lordſhip ſitting (riſes), that will look like want of reſpect. I will be ſtanding. No—that will not be the thing neither; for then I ſhall have no opportunity to ſhew my veneration, by riſing at his entrance. No—I muſt ſit, and—Yes, there I've hit it—I'll be reading—deeply employed in reading. Then, when the great man enters, ſtart up, and daſh away the book. Let me ſee—it ſhall be a large book. I'll get up and reach one down. (mounts the library ſteps, and takes down a book) —Chambers's Dictionary—that will do. (Takes down another) "The Fall of the Roman Empire." Bleſs me—my lord!

div.stage:
(A ſervant announces Lord Beechgrove. Sir Robert looking round ſees Tippy enter, dreſſed as
Lord Beechgrove, followed by Fancourt. In his fright he tumbles with the books from the ſteps. They help him up.)

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: O, dear! I am quite confounded. My lord, I beg your lordſhip's pardon a million of times. Mr. Fancourt—O, my knee! (rubs it) Reach his lordſhip a chair. A moſt untoward accident, my lord; but pray accept it as an omen. You found me ſprawling at your feet—it ſhews how devoted I am to your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Tippy,
sp.p: Sir Robert, I have often heard of the politeneſs of the Welch gentlemen, and you really confirm all that has been ſaid. The year in which you were ſheriff, Sir Robert, was ſuch a year of ſplendour and magnificence, as Glamorganſhire will long remember. We heard a vaſt deal of it at Saint James's; it amuſed the Royal Circle for a month.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Why, my lord, I did my beſt on that occaſion. When I was high ſheriff for the county, I neither ſpared myſelf or my purſe. A hanging in the morning, and an aſſembly at night; giving the judges a dinner to-day, and to-morrow conſulting Jack Ketch about a new gallows. Such a variety of buſineſs, my lord, demands a man's whole attention.

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p:
Certainly, certainly. A little thing happened this morning, Sir Robert, which has given me pain. You addreſſed me in the Park, I really was, at that moment, throwing over in my mind the compact between Ruſſia and Poland. In ſhort, I had almoſt determined to go to Saint Peterſburgh, ambaſſador myſelf; for I think one or two points might be reviſed. At that very moment, Sir Robert, juſt as I was
delivering my credentials to the Empreſs, and receiving one of thoſe delicious ſmiles, which—

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: You will go too far. (twitching him)

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: I ſay, juſt then, Sir Robert, you addreſſed me.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: No wonder, my lord, that you overlooked me; I am aſhamed to have made a complaint of ſuch a trifle.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Pray, my lord, examine Sir Robert's ſhelves; you will find them well ſtocked.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: All dead ſtock, my lord; heavy dead ſtock.

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Pardon me, Sir, pardon me! Such ſtock is never dead. You have here in calf's-ſkin and ſheep's-ſkin, the very ſouls of the authors. Well choſen, I dare ſay.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Why, my lord, as to the choice, I left that to my broker. He furniſhed the whole houſe, from the kitchen to the garret; the pots and the poets; the frying-pans and the philoſophers were all of his chooſing.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Now, Sir Robert, if you would do the thing genteely, write the draft without his obſerving it, and I'll preſent it to him after we have left the houſe. Great men muſt not have ſervices tendered them coarſely.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: I underſtand you; there is a nice way of doing things. Pray, my lord, amuſe yourſelf with a folio or two. A certain delicate—it ſhall be ſo. (goes and writes)

sp.speaker: Tippy
sp.p: (taking up a book). "The debates of Leadenhall-ſtreet." Pleaſant reading—light— pretty reading in a heavy morning!

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Leadenhall-ſtreet—A thought ſtrikes me.

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Then ſtrike again.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: I ſay, my lord, as Sir Robert is a liberal man, and fond of patronage, ſuppoſe you give him, by way of outſet, a place at the Board of Controul for Indian affairs, juſt till a better thing offers. (Sir Robert writes, and liſtens by turns).

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: The thought was too obvious to be miſſed—exactly ſuits his diſcernment and ſpirit. (whiſpers, then ſpeaks audibly) The nabobs (whiſpers) —the begums (whiſpers) —muſlins, alaballas, mul-muls, and nanſooks (whiſpers), Nankeen china (whiſpers), Patna rice (whiſpers).

sp.speaker: Sir Robert
sp.p: (runs up). O, my lord! my lord! (ſlides the draft into Fancourt's hands) Not a word—mum! (his finger to his lip)

div.stage: (Fancourt holds up the draft to catch Tippy's eye.)

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Faith, I had better go about it directly—no time to be loſt—let us finiſh the buſineſs at once. (looking ſignificantly at Fancourt) Sir Robert, your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Sir Robert, your ſervant. (both hurrying off)

sp.speaker: Sir Robert
sp.p: (ſtands and ſtares). "Sir Robert, your ſervant"—mighty ſhort! Well, but they're in a hurry to ſerve me—a little rudeneſs, when it proceeds from kindneſs, may be pardoned.

div.stage: Enter GEORGINA haſtily, followed by JENNY.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: O! dear papa, there is a woman in the ſquare with ſome odd muſic; I am going to the bow-window to hear her. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Get along, madcap! (going) begums, nabobs, Patna rice—Sir Robert, your ſervant—mighty ſhort! Exit.

div.head: SCENE III.—The ſquare.
div.stage: Mrs. FANCOURT, dreſſed as a Savoyard, enters, winding a hurdy gurdy, attended by two children, the one with a tambour, the other with a cymbal.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p:
This is the houſe; here will I place myſelf—fortunately I may attract the lovely victim. (ſings and plays)
I be von poor Savoyard,
Get but lit, and labour hard;
Wet and cold me oft' endure,
Patience be my only cure.
GEORGINA appears, JENNY ſtands behind her.
Ah, Ah, charmante lady, caſt down your bright eye,
Compaſſionate look, or perhaps I be die;
I ſee von ſweet ſmile ſtealing over your face,
It give you new beauty, it give you new grace,
I be von poor Savoyard,
Get but lit, and labour hard;
Wet and cold me oft endure,
Patience be my only cure.
Make von curteſy to de lady, you lit impudent ting.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Do not chide her. Where did you come from?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: From von great vay off; I live among de mountains, and I be come to make pleaſe de prit lady of dis country. (Georgina throws down ſilver.) Take up l'argent, ma petite, and put it in votre poche—Bleſs your charité. Lady, I can tell de fortune by looking at de vite hand.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Can you? O! dear Jenny, let us have her up.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Laws, Miſs, don't let ſuch creatures come in; they may ſteal ſomething; there's a wicked look in her eyes; I underſtand eyes as well as ſhe does hands.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Dat prit young voman's by your ſide, lady, be born to von great luck— ſhe vill ave de grande offer.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Well, Miſs, if you will have her in— I'll go and open the door.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Thus far I am ſucceſsful. O! horrid! that ſuch youth and goodneſs ſhould become the prey of two villains! Ah! the door opens.

sp.speaker: Jenny
sp.p: (opening the door). Come, come—make haſte. They enter.

div.head: SCENE—Changes to the Drawing-room.
div.stage: GEORGINA enters, followed by Mrs. FANCOURT and JENNY.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Come, let me look at your prit vite hand. (takes Georgina's hand, and pretends to examine the lines.) Ah, I ſee—I ſee— But I ave not de power to tell de fortune before any von—dat gentle—ſweet temper young vomans muſt go.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Go, Jenny, d'ye hear? Leave the room; go directly.

sp.speaker: Jenny
sp.p: (going reluctantly). I ſhou'd not have thought of that foreign woman's impudence, to have me ſent out of the room—I don't like her—I'll liſten, I am determined. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Now, Miſs, me vill tell you —you be born to be ver happy, if you be ver good.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Dear! Do you think I am not good?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Bau! Bau! dere be von— two vicked mens, who ave de vicked deſign upon you—Il faut, you muſt not ſee gentlemens, but in de preſence of your papa. Your papa be your bon friend.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: I never heard any thing ſo ridiculous. Never ſee gentlemen, but in my papa's preſence. O! you are a fine fortune-teller! Good-day (going).

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt
sp.p: (is agitated; follows, and ſeizes her). Madam, if you would not be loſt beyond redemption, obſerve what I have ſaid. Two villains have laid ſuch a train—

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Amazing! Why, you now ſpeak good Engliſh.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Hah! I had forgot; but when the heart feels it is hard to diſſemble. You have detected me. Charming young woman, ſlight not the cautions which I wear this diſguiſe to give! Surely they muſt have weight with you, when I tell you, that it is perhaps at the hazard of my life, that I appear before you.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: You freeze me!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p:
Treat not lightly then the advice of one, who runs ſuch riſks to preſs it
upon you—I know not exactly what is deſigned —I have awakened your caution, and my duty is compleat.

sp.speaker: Jenny
sp.p: (running in). Get out of the houſe, you impoſtor—you deceiving jezabel. If you do not go this minute, I will order the footman to ſweep you out.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Young lady think upon my words. Exit.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Think upon her words—a vagabond! did you ever ſee ſuch aſſurance, Miſs? I have a great mind to beat her hurdy-gurdy about her ears.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Be ſilent! what I have heard ſhall ſink into my heart. I will be circumſpect (walking ſlowly and gravely off).

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Here's a pretty kettle of fiſh! who can that vile woman be? Jack has let ſomebody into our ſecret, who has betrayed us. What labour it will coſt me to throw her off her guard! but I'll try (takes a letter from her pocket, and looks it over). Yes, yes; this letter will bring Jack. Hang me, if I don't believe I have ſpelt diſguiſe wrong. Well, no matter—the meaning is undiſguiſed enough (wafers the letter). Here Humphrey! (ſmiling, and ſpeaking very gently) Humphrey!
Come, none of your flummery.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p:
Nay, don't be croſs—you know we have made it up—here, take this letter, and carry it to my brother Jack. Come now, (coaxingly) you know I am working you the
corners of a new handkerchief, twenty times as pretty as this (touching that which he wears).

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.p: Shall I have it by Friday, when I go to Bob's wedding?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: You ſhall. (bell rings)

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.p: Well, give it me (ſnatching the letter). The old place, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Yes, yes, the old place (bell again). Hang the bell—go directly. Exit.

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.p: The wafer's wet, ha, ha, ha! now ſhe thinks I can't read wroiting—help her ſappy head! ha, ha, ha! I can read and wroite too, but that's a ſecret between me and my ownſelf (looking at it all round). I would not break a ſeal for the world—for that I know would be a moſt unhonorable thing; but as to a chambermaid's wet wafer—there—it opens like a boil'd oyſter.

'Tis a dainty ſcrawl. The lines run as ſtraight as the zig-zag of a ſcrew. (reads) "LovingBrother,"—well that's koind— "cum here to-morrow in your old diſguiſe—I mean the (ſpelling) f—e—m—fem. (looking earneſtly) f—e, fe. M. by itſelf M." Yes, it is female— "and call yourſelf, as before, Miſs Sally Martin." So, ſo! then that ſtrapping wench that I have let in ſometimes, is all the while her brother Jack. (ſcratches his head, and reads again) "There's ſomething in the wind—we muſt make ſhort work—be ſure you come— your affectionate ſiſter, Jane."

So Jack and Jane are a pretty pair; now, what can they be upon? that's nothing to I— I think I won't carry it—yes, (looks at the corners of his handkerchief) yes, I think I will—I
will carry it—I will ſee Jack in petticoats once more. Exit.

div.head: SCENE V.—St. James's Park.
div.stage: TIPPY walking backwards and forwards with an air of great uneaſineſs—FANCOURT appears.

sp.speaker: Tippy
sp.p: (running towards him) O! you are come (breathleſs). I have been waiting here theſe two hours. I began to fear that you were ſlippery —that you were upon your tricks.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: What, with each other? O fye! never. I drove to the banker's and back as faſt as the horſes of a wretched hack could carry me. In my way I met a fellow in his chariot, who two years ſince borrowed money of me for ſhoes.

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: I never ſhall meet ſuch a fellow, for I never lend—make a point of that. Come, give me the money—my moiety of the thouſand pounds.

sp.speaker: Fancourt
sp.p: (unwilling). Directly—directly— ha! how d'ye do? (bowing to thoſe ſuppos'd to be paſſing). Here is the— (puts his hand ſlowly in his pocket). Ha! I ſaw you laſt night (to others) a full concert. I ſhall be at the tennis-court preſently (running off towards the top).

sp.speaker: Tippy
sp.p: (following). Rot the tennis-court! give me the notes.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: The notes! well, there are the notes.

div.stage: (Tippy looks at the notes aſtoniſhed, and at Fancourt by turns).

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Well, what are theſe?

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: What are they? why, the notes— your ſhare of the thouſand pounds procured by me this morning (careleſsly).

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Here are five notes, five and twenty pounds each.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: What, can't you reckon? four notes, five and twenty pounds each, make one hundred—one hundred pounds, principal money. Dear Tippy, do not look ſo thunderſtruck—you are very welcome. I confeſs I had ſome thoughts of making it fifty; but recollecting our antient friendſhip, when I bought into the four per cents. with the reſt, I reſerved a whole hundred for you. Good day, Tippy.

sp.speaker: Tippy
sp.p: (ſeizing him). Stay, Sir—ſtay you ſhall (fiercely).

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Nay, my good fellow, do not make an uproar in the Park; becauſe you know if you do, Tippy, I ſhall be under the neceſſity of relating ſome little anecdotes of you, which may end in a proceſſion to Newgate.

sp.speaker: Tippy
sp.p: (trembling with paſſion). So, you have bought nine hundred pounds ſtock?

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: I have.

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: And you are determined I ſhall touch but one.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Only one, Tippy.

sp.speaker: Tippy
sp.p: (ſmothering rage). Very well—very well.

sp.speaker: Fancourt
sp.p: (in a paſſion). Zounds! what wou'd the man have? an hundred pounds for only juſt walking into an old ſprawling fellow's library —and—the devil!—he's here—I'm off!— (runs off).

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Is he? he is—no, I'll not run—he's coming towards me—I'll not flinch. Now you ſhall ſee, Mr. Fancourt, what it is to uſe a brother raſcal ill. Is not the world wide enough for our tricks, but we muſt cheat one another? I'll ſacrifice myſelf rather than not be revenged. (Takes out his pocket book and pencil, ſeeming very intent).

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Hah! there's his Lordſhip—he ſeems very buſy—perhaps I had better paſs on —no, I won't—ſurely, after ſuch a favour— Hah! my Lord, your moſt obedient. (Tippy looks at him, gazes, then continues to write). Well now I declare (looks amazed). My Lord, I ſay, your moſt obedient.

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, who are you?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: I am aſtoniſhed!

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Who, I ſay, are you; who thus, twice have taken the freedom to addreſs me in public?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Who am I? what, does not your Lordſhip know me now? O! perhaps the delicious ſmiles of the Empreſs are in your Lordſhip's head again—perhaps the Poliſh treaty— perhaps—

sp.speaker: Tippy
sp.p: (in a feigned paſſion). Perhaps neither of theſe! I am engroſſed by your impertinence. Who are you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Who am I? why, the man who, two hours ſince, lent you a thouſand pounds, principal money, to keep you from the gripe of the Jews.

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: A thouſand pounds. Eh, eh! (looking very gravely). Lent me a thouſand pounds! Sir, (ſeizing his hand) I am full of concern for you—I ſee you have been impoſed on. Sir, there is a fellow about this town ſo like me, that we might play the two Socias, or the two Dromios, or paſs for two brown ruſſetans growing on the ſame twig. He reſembles my perſon; he imitates my very dreſs—Sir, depend on it, he has alſo aſſumed my name, and has ſwindled you out of one thouſand pounds, principal money.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Why, my Lord, I am thunder-ſtruck. Then, what you ſaid to me this morning—I mean what he ſaid, concerning the Begums, and the Nanſooks—

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Was all to cozen you, depend on't. You are cheated, I ſee clearly. Sorry for you —can't ſtay—clearly cheated, Sir, depend on't (going).

sp.speaker: Sir Robert
sp.p: (much agitated). My Lord—my Lord, grant me a moment—permit me to aſk one queſtion—do you know Mr. Fancourt?

sp.speaker: Tippy
sp.p: (with ſcorn). Do I know Mr. Fancourt, Sir! there are a ſort of people one may be ſaid to know, becauſe one meets them every where. But as to Mr. Fancourt, why, Sir, I would not keep a groom who was acquainted with ſuch a —ſuch a perſon.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: If you want to find his character, you will hear of it in Bow-ſtreet; if you want to find his lodgings, you muſt go to St. Giles's. Do I know Mr. Fancourt indeed! Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p:
Is it ground I ſtand upon? I am amazed—never were two men ſo alike on earth.
The look—the voice—the dreſs—but can Fancourt be a villain? no, it is not poſſible; to me he cannot be a villain—yet—I know not what to conjecture.
Ente FANCOURT behind, grinning, and claps him on the ſhoulder.
(Turns and gazes on him). No—his looks are innocent—it is not poſſible that he can be guilty.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: How d'ye do, Knight? how d'ye do?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Yet I'll try him (looks ſternly). Sir, I have ſeen a man who tells me you are a villain.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: 'Tis well he does not let me ſee him. But who is the man—who is he, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Lord Beechgrove—the real Lord Beechgrove, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Hell and ten thouſand furies! (aſide) explain, Sir, explain! I really cannot poſſibly comprehend you.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: He tells me, Sir, that the man you brought to me to-day, is an impoſtor, and that in concert with him, you have cheated me of a thouſand pounds.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: How, Sir, an impoſtor! (in a rage) but I'll be cool—I'll be cool—where was you told of this—where, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: On this very ſpot, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fancourt
sp.p: (aſide). Hah! I begin to ſmoke— what, Lord Beechgrove has juſt left you then?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: This moment—I found him here.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p:
So, this is Tippy's damn'd revenge! (aſide) ha, ha, ha! O what a—ha, ha,
ha! what a droll dog! why, Sir, do you not know that my noble friend is the greateſt joker in England? ha, ha, ha! I ſuppoſe he might tell you there was a man about town who reſembled him?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: He did—he did ſure enough— he ſaid they were as like as two drums.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Ay, ay, he plays thoſe tricks continually—he is inexhauſtible as a joker. O! the raſcal! (aſide).

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: That's very odd in a Privy Counſellor.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p:
It is by way of unbending, Sir— thoſe great men muſt unbend. The lion muſt dandle the kid ſometimes—the villain! (aſide) I could tell you ſuch tales of him. Hah! here his Lordſhip comes.
Enter TIPPY. (Runs up to him) You ſhall have the other four hundred (apart).

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Ah, ah, Sir Robert—what, I frightened you, did I?—I ſhan't truſt you (apart to Fancourt).

sp.speaker: Fancourt
sp.p: (giving him notes). Take it—here it is—the dog has been up to me this time (aſide). Really, my Lord, it was not right to play on Sir Robert's credulity. He could not know but that you might be in earneſt. But I muſt particularly inſiſt on one thing, my Lord, that you do not ſpeak of my character in ſuch terms, though in jeſt. The jeſt which laughs away a man's reputation, is deadly poiſon adminiſtered in honey.

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p:
Well, I won't—I won't. What do
you think I told him, Fancourt? I told him you lived at St. Giles's, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: No!—did you?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: He did indeed, ha, ha, ha! and that you were known in Bow-ſtreet, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Well, now I propoſe that we three jolly fellows, full of good humour, and lovers of fun, daſh off to the Star and Garter—Champaigne and a ſong ſhall cheer our hearts, and ſet us above the cares of the world.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: With all my heart. Rattle glaſſes with a Lord—h—m—m— (with ſecret delight) it will be as good as dining with a Dutcheſs.

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Come along, my little fellow; I'll introduce you to three Lords, and a Duke.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Here then we go—jeſt, mirth and pleaſure inſpire us!

div.stage: They take Sir Robert between them and go off, wave their hats, and huzza.

div.head: SCENE I.—TIPPY's Lodgings.
div.stage: Enter Mrs. BULLRUSH, bringing in the Gown ſhe wore in the firſt ſcene, work bag, &c.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bullruſh.
sp.p: I'll take poſſeſſion of his room myſelf, hang me if I don't! (ſits down) here am I obliged to mend my gowns inſtead of buying new ones, becauſe my lodgers won't pay me (threads a needle). No, no, Mr. Tippy— I'll fit you! I ſpoke to my neighbour Holdfaſt, yeſterday; no one ever got out of his clutches yet, if once Holdfaſt touch'd him on the ſhoulder (works a little), Bleſs me! how my teeth torment me again (puts up her handkerchief) Betty! Betty—bring me a little brandy to hold in my mouth. I'll e'en go myſelf, ſhe always brings ſuch a drop! Exit.

div.stage: Enter TIPPY, with a Letter in his hand.

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p:
Yes, yes—tell them ſo— (ſpeaking gaily) no, my artful ſiſter, it won't do (reading) Wear the ſame diſguiſe, and come as Miſs Sally Martin. That is not poſſible—my landlady's maid, who uſed to lend me that ſmart dreſs, is off. What the devil can I do? to go there as a man, after having juſt been there as Lord Beechgrove, would be kicking down the milk pail with a vengeance! and yet to loſe that ſweet girl and her ſweet eſtate— well, I can't go—I cannot go to Sir Robert's,
pos! (going out, runs againſt the table). What's this? my landlady's gown? gad it is! (opens it) if it fits me, I'll borrow it to perſonate Miſs Sally Martin (puts it on). Hang me, but it does very well. She has often ſaid, ſhe would fit me, and now ſhe has done it. And the ſmart bonnet too (puts it on). Freeze me, but I look as well as my landlady. Who—who the devil is this? (looking thro' the door) HOLDFAST, the Bailiff? whu! I am in the jaws of the lion!

sp.speaker: Holdfaſt.
sp.p:
Well, Madam, is Mr. Tippy come home? I have been watching for him the whole day (Tippy groans). I have been hunting him through every tavern, coffee-houſe, and gaming-houſe. I have been within three minutes of him, fifteen times. O! that I had but hold of his ſkirts! (Tippy groans). Alack-a-day, Mrs. Bullruſh, ſtill plagued with your teeth? (Tippy makes motions with his hand). Well, Madam, don't ſpeak. If I once catch the young villain, we ſha'n't part, (Tippy groans) I have one room double grated, and if he ſlides out of that, it muſt be thro' the keyhole. (Tippy groans, gets up, and puts Holdfaſt into his chair, making motions). Very well—I underſtand you. I'll ſtay here till you come back, Mrs. Bullruſh; yes—I will. Exit. Tippy groaning. Poor creature! her teeth torment her like— what the dickens! why there's Mrs. Bullruſh! (looking out) a trick! a trick! (bawling out) no— yes—'tis all in white! (looks ſcared) perhaps—
Mrs. Bullruſh—Mrs. Bullruſh! oh! (goes off trembling and frighten'd).

div.head: SCENE II.—SIR SIMON ASGILL's Counting-Houſes.—He is ſeated, looking melancholy and oppreſs'd.
div.stage: PERKINS enters—he looks at SIR SIMON with great concern.

sp.speaker: Perkins.
sp.p: Sir, Sir—I pray you, Sir, ſpeak!

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Perkins! I have carried it too far. My boy can no where be found. Why did I hit on ſuch a plan? I ought to have known that the ſenſibility of his heart, and the nobleneſs of his ſoul, could neither ſupport ſeeing my diſtreſs, or living a uſeleſs member of ſociety.

sp.speaker: Perkins.
sp.p: Sir, be comforted—it is not yet noon; perhaps the evening may bring us tidings.
A lady, Sir, deſires to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: I can ſee no lady (petulantly).

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: She is particularly preſſing, and requeſts to ſee you alone.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Who is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: I have never ſeen her. Her ſervants are in mourning (a pauſe). Shall I conduct her to the drawing-room, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p:
No—if I muſt ſee her, bring her in here. The counting-houſe of an Engliſh merchant is reſpectable enough for the reception
of a prince;—I ſhould not be aſhamed to receive my king in it. (exit. Servant). Well, Perkins, you find the lady will have me alone—if I was in ſpirits to joke now, I could make myſelf merry at the fancy.

sp.speaker: Perkins.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I hope your ſpirits and your jokes will ſoon come back. Faith, ſhe's a pretty lady Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Your humble ſervant, Madam. (She curtſeys, and ſeems confuſed). Pray ſit down.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: I thank you. (He ſtands by her chair—ſhe fans herſelf).

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: You ſeem faint, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: No, Sir—no. In a moment I ſhall be better.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Not uſed, perhaps, to the buſtle of driving thro' the City?

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: Not often. O! how ſhall I begin? my heart burſts with feeling, yet my tongue cannot give it utterance (aſide).

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Pray may I aſk—what brought you here to-day?

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: To-day, Sir—I came to-day (breathleſs) on a buſineſs ſo important—that— I ſcarcely know how to mention it, Sir—but— you have a nephew (looking on her fan).

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: I hope ſo, Ma'am.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: You have heard of Lady Horatia Horton,

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Heard of her—yes—I have heard of her!

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: It is believ'd, Sir, that Mr. Aſgill has ſome regard for her.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: I hope not. My nephew, I believe, knows better than to regard ſuch a gill-flirt.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: Gill-flirt! Lady Horatia Horton, a gill-flirt.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Yes—the greateſt gill-flirt I ever ſaw in my life.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia
sp.p: (riſing). Ah, he means Georgina, who ſaw him yeſterday. I am ſo confuſed, I know not how to explain (aſide).

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: My nephew in love with a ſtone-cutter!

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: A hewer of marble! why he may as well live in a quarry.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: Monſtrous! (aſide).

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Her ſtudy is a work-ſhop—her drawing-room a maſon's ſaw-yard.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia
sp.p: (aſide). Inſupportable! can this be the uncle of Sidney Aſgill?

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: There ſhe chiſſels out womens' faces with young ſerpents hanging in drop curls, by way of a new faſhion'd tete.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia
sp.p: (in great warmth). Nay, I can bear it no longer! Sir, this more than gothic ignorance, is a diſgrace to the age in which we live, and to your own ſituation. The head of the beautiful MEDUSA is amongſt the wonders of the art. O! the more than martial ſkill, which could make BEAUTY horrible!

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Hey! The dumb lady cured! what is ſhe crazy?

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p:
At the ſame place you ſaw
(with enthuſiaſm) the touching NIOBE, mourning over her children;—the light ATALANTA flying from her lover—the graceful GANYMEDE caught up to Olympus for his beauty, did none of thoſe ſtrike ye? none of thoſe awaken your adoration for the ſublime art,—for SCULPTURE! whoſe long enduring beauties bid defiance to time, and laugh at ages!

sp.speaker: Sir Simon
sp.p: (ſinging). "I am mad Beſs, believe me."

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: Your coarſeneſs, Sir, is hardly to be borne! how different from yours is the mind of your nephew! he has ſat whole hours admiring thoſe wonders of the art, and patiently watching the ſtrokes of the chiſſel, which preſumed at diſtant imitation.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: It is the firſt inſtance of his folly I ever heard. I thought Sidney had been a different ſort of a man.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe you have been employing your talents to the more exalted purpoſes of importing verdigreaſe, and blubber, and in making monopolies.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Monopolies! no, Madam, never! there is one monopoly, and only one, to which I give my aſſent;—may the poſterity of Engliſhmen continue to monopolize this little iſland, as long as the ſea fills its channel, or the winds blow upon its rocks! have you any commiſſion for me, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: Commiſſion—Sir—I came— I intended—it was my deſign—no, Sir, I have no commiſſion.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p:
When you have, Madam, I ſhall be happy to ſee you again, but I really have not
had time to read my letters, which I muſt beg to do directly. Order the lady's carriage.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: Sir—I really feel myſelf ſo inſulted that—perhaps, Sir—but no matter. Perhaps you are right—yes, Sir, you are very right (goes out weeping, yet with dignity).

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Perkins! come in Perkins! (he enters) why I was never ſo ſtunn'd in my life. Here's a woman comes on pretence to ſpeak about my nephew, and then begins ſome gibberiſh about ſculpture,—and talks of Ganymede, and Atalanta, and Olympus, and ſuch vile traſh as lads learn out of Ovid; books, that if I was a member of parliament, I'd bring in a bill to make it felony for any bookſeller to vend.

sp.speaker: Perkins.
sp.p: It would do you more honor, Sir, than any canal bill, bill for roads, or any other improvement that was ever brought before the Houſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Hah, Mr. Conway, what news— what news? (running towards him).

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Alas! none, Sir. I have follow'd our poor Sidney by every poſſible clue that I could obtain; but he has paſs'd away like a vapour— not a trace remains (ſighing).

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: O! fye—O! fye. (ſhaking his head with a melancholy air).

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe Lady Horatia Horton has been here to make enquiries.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Lady Horatia Horton. She ſtept into her carriage as I came up to the gate— but ſhe ſeem'd to be weeping, ſo I avoided her.

sp.speaker: Perkins.
sp.p: Bleſs me, Sir—there has been ſome miſtake. (to Sir Simon)

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: I don't know—I am all in a wood! why, was that lady in mourning, Lady Horatia Horton?

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Aſſuredly.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Why 'tis quite a different perſon from her I ſaw, yeſterday, at her houſe.

sp.speaker: Conway
sp.p: (ſmiling). O yes, ha, ha—I have heard about that. The lady you ſaw was quite a different perſon.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Gad I hope I ſhall never have the luck to ſee her again.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Why, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: I can't endure her.

sp.speaker: Conway
sp.p: (angrily). Sir! not endure her? why, ſhe is the moſt charming of her ſex. That lady, Sir, has more ſweetneſs of diſpoſition, more playful innocence of heart, and more beauty than half the women in the world.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: I hope I may form a different opinion, Mr. Conway.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: No, Sir—no man ſhall form a different opinion—or if he does, he muſt take care to conceal it in my preſence.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: I ſhall take no care, Sir. I will uſe the freedom of an Engliſhman to ſpeak all I think of you, and of every man, and of every woman too. How dared ſhe aſſume a character ſhe was not?—how dared ſhe ſay ſuch things of my nephew to my face?

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Sir! whatever that lady ſays, I make myſelf anſwerable for.

sp.speaker: Perkins.
sp.p: O, Gentlemen, let me entreat you! —you will both be ſorry—you have been both too warm.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: I adviſe you to perſuade Sir Simon that he has been ſo!—I ſhall expect his apology.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon
sp.p: (ſtaring). Why, what's in the wind to-day, Perkins! I affront every one who comes near me, without deſigning it, I am ſure.

sp.speaker: Perkins.
sp.p: Your temper has been a little ruffled, Sir; you are ſore about Mr. Aſgill.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Sore indeed! and my heart will be ſore ſoon, as well as my temper, if I do not hear of him, But about this Lady Horatia— 'tis very odd! what could bring her here? perhaps ſhe came to tell me ſome news. I think I will go to her.

sp.speaker: Perkins.
sp.p: It would be beſt, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: I certainly will—after change. But I hope I ſhall not ſee her marble monſters again—they'll put me out of ſorts if I do. What a taſte!

sp.speaker: Perkins.
sp.p: Dear Sir, any taſte is better than no taſte, and a lady who employs her thoughts and her chiſſel on works of art, is, at leaſt, not idle; and, therefore, as Doctor Johnſon ſays, not in the way of being wicked. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE changes to SIR ROBERT's Drawing-Room.

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.p: Why, what a noddy have I been, to take this ſtrapper always for a girl! (aſide).

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: What is the oaf grinning at? do as I bid you—tell Mrs. Jenny her friend Miſs Sally Martin is here. Humprey goes out, making faces. Gad, I had a good run. I was hardly ſafe in the hack, before the bailiff and my landlady were in purſuit.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: O! Jack, I am ſo—

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Huſh! come to the point. I am in danger every moment that I ſtay. What progreſs have you made with your miſtreſs! What is to be done?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Why what is to be done, is to get her any way into your power—once get her to your lodgings, and a marriage muſt follow.

sp.speaker: Tippy
sp.p: (ſneeringly). Good!

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: I have prevail'd on her to go with me alone, to the famous wax-work. She knows not where it is, ſo I'll bring her in a hack to your lodgings; and then—mercy! here ſhe comes—what ſhall we do?

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Do!—upon my ſoul ſhe's a ſweet creature! I hope ſhe won't detect the Connoiſeur, in petticoats.

div.stage: GEORGINA enters—TIPPY bows very low— recovers himſelf, and curtſeys.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Bleſs me, Jenny—who is this?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: A— ſtranger Ma'am—a lady that. Did you not ſay, Madam, that you ran into the hall to avoid ſome gentlemen who were rude to you? (to Tippy) and then, Miſs, that blundering fellow, Humphrey, brought him up—I mean brought the lady up here.

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Yes, Ma'am, he brought me up here. Really a modeſt woman can hardly walk the ſtreets, men are ſo impertinent. One gentleman ſeiz'd my hand; d—n you, Sir, ſays I— I mean I ſaid, bleſs me, Sir, I beg you won't be rude.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: A very odd lady, Jenny!

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Curſe the petticoats! Madam I ſcorn to impoſe on you—no, Madam, I have a ſoul above it—I am not a lady. I put on this diſguiſe to procure admiſſion here, that I might tell you how I adore you, Madam (kneeling) my paſſion for you is ſo great, that if you do not look on me with pity—if you do not liſten to me with compaſſion— (Jenny ſhrieks).

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: A lady at my daughter's feet! (Tippy ſtarts up) ſome great favour ſure ſhe is aſking. What did you ſhriek for?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p:
Shriek, Sir—O, Sir, the poor lady —ſhe was ſaying as how that ſhe had a cruel huſband—I never heard of ſuch a villain! and ſhe was deploring Miſs to ſpeak to you in the
affair, for you know him. He ſeems a moſt ſweet young fellow, Ma'am, it would be great pity to betray him! (aside)

sp.speaker: Georgina
sp.p: (to herſelf). The Savoyard! O, I remember all at this moment!

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Do I know your huſband, Ma'am! Pray do not wheel round in this manner— there's nothing ſhameful in having a bad huſband—if there were, few married women would care to ſhew their faces.

sp.speaker: Tippy
sp.p: (in a ſhrill voice). O, Sir, I ſhould die with confuſion. (ſtill keeping his back to Sir Robert).

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, is the fault all your huſband's?

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: O, entirely, Sir;—my behaviour to him is quite angelic.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: I dare ſay your face is angelic, if one could but ſee it (ſtill wheeling to get a peep at her). Perhaps you live a little too gaily for him, poor man!

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Not at all! I am a pattern of prudence —generally at home by four in the morning. Charming creature! pity my diſtreſs! (in his own voice to Georgina).

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Pray Ma'am turn, and ſhew yourſelf to my Papa, and if you tell him the ſame affecting ſtory you began to me—

sp.speaker: Jenny
sp.p: (apart). Nay pray, Ma'am, do not betray him! how can you have the heart? he would die rather than do you an ill turn. Did you obſerve what teeth he has?

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Sweet lady, ſpeak! a deſign ſo pure, and eloquence ſo irreſiſtable, will affect Sir Robert as it ought.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Sweet lady turn round! gad, there's ſome fudge here—I am ſure there is. Sir Robert take my advice—look in the lady's face.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert
sp.p: (goes to her). Nay, Madam, 'tis in vain. I will ſee your bright eyes, or never — (Tippy trips up Sir Robert, and then attempts to run off).

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: A Thalaſtris, by Jupiter! (ſeizing Tippy) nay, I will have a peep, ſpite of your dexterity, Miſs! (Tippy ſtruggles) come, to the right about! by Heavens this muſt be a man— Sir Robert, I ſmell a rat (turns him). Zounds! what Tippy! I am a bit of a Marplot here. This comes of your entruſting your friends by halves (apart).

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: What it is a man, then! I thought it was the moſt robuſt damſel I had ever met with.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Get out of the houſe (puſhing him). You might well hide your face! get out, or I will make you ſhew it at the Old Bailey (drives him out).

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Who is he?

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Oh, a fellow who lives by his wits; one whoſe ſtock in trade is all in the pia mater. (touching his forehead).

sp.speaker: Sir Robert
sp.p: (to Georgina). How came he here in this diſguiſe? where have you ſeen him? I inſiſt on knowing the truth.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: She ſeems ſadly puzzled—the girl has been taught that 'tis a ſin to tell lies.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Why don't you ſpeak, Georgina? come be bold! your prompter I ſee is at your elbow.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Pray ſpeak, Miſs. Say it is your ſtaymaker. (aſide)

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Yes, I will ſpeak. I aſſure you, Sir, (taking her father's hand) I never ſaw that perſon till now; but a circumſtance which, I believe, muſt relate to him, has ſtruck my recollection, and makes me ſhudder.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: What is it, child?

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Sir—I—yeſterday, Sir, I had my fortune told.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Pho!

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, mine was no common fortune-teller; ſhe was certainly a well-bred woman in diſguiſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Why, what did ſhe ſay to you?

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: She told me that two men—two moſt unprincipled monſters, had laid a plot for my deſtruction (he ſtarts). Her diſguiſe was that of a Savoyard, with muſic.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Whu! (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: I remember you ran through the library to go to liſten to her.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Pray—pray, Madam, what ſort of a perſon was this pretended Savoyard?

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: An agreeable little woman, with eyes full of intelligence, and manners full of good ſenſe.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Yes, it was my devil, I ſee clearly. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: This ſeeming lady is probably one of the two men I had notice of, who introduced himſelf here, to carry on deſigns which make me tremble.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p:
I believe you do, my dear. I never ſaw you ſo grave, nor heard you talk ſo diſcreetly before; a little fright has done you
good. May you never ceaſe to tremble, Georgina, when you recollect the hazards of this hour!

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: You, Jenny, have always nouriſh'd my follies, and cheriſh'd my abſurdities; I will never hold communication with you more. Go directly to the houſekeeper, receive your wages, and leave my father's houſe. Begone!

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Why, ſhe can never mean this in earneſt; this muſt be all fudge before her father. (goes heſitatingly.)

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: O! that every miſguided daughter would retrieve her errors before it be too late, and, like you, take ſhelter in the arms of a fond and forgiving father! (embracing her.) My dear Georgina, I wiſh thou hadſt either a mother, or a huſband!

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: A moſt edifying ſcene, this! (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Mr. Fancourt, you know who this fellow is.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Not abſolutely know him—I have ſeen him; and I will trace him out, Sir, if it be poſſible. And I'll find your little Savoyard too, Madam; your pretty fortune-teller; it ſhall go hard but I'll meet with her! Exit.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: O! I wiſh he may diſcover her, for I ſhall cheriſh burning gratitude towards her, to the laſt hour of my exiſtence! My dear Sir, I feel like one of our little Welch kids at home, trembling on the brink of a monſtrous precipice, when its ſond parent appears, and guides back its feeble ſteps, to crop the flow'ry herbage in ſafety.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon
sp.p: (entering). Madam, your moſt obedient. I did not know that you were Lady Horatia Horton this morning; ſo I came to apologize, and all that.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: An unnceſſary trouble, Sir. (coldly.)

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Not at all, Madam, not at all. If I offend, I am always ready to make amends. A little gipſey yeſterday took your name, and railed at Sidney; I could not bear it.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: And was it therefore, Sir, that you inſulted my art? Was it therefore that you laughed at, and abuſed my—

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Your monſters, Madam. O! keep clear of them, whatever you do! Don't talk of them!

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: Why, is this poſſible?

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Madam, this life is too ſhort to ſquander time upon triſles; ſo, let us come to the point! I am told that you have a great regard for my nephew, and I love and admire you for it; talk of him, and we ſhall agree to the end of the chapter.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: The perſon who told you ſo, Sir, took an unwarrantable freedom.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Why, you told me ſo yourſelf. Would any lady fly into the city, to talk to a croſs old fellow about his nephew, if ſhe had not ſet her heart upon him? Pho! pho! that ſpoke your ſentiments pretty plainly.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia
sp.p: (weeping with vexation). O dear! I tell you, I hate your nephew?

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Do you? O, you woman! You downright woman! I ſee how it is. When he was rich, you loved him; when you looked forward to fine equipage, ſplendour and expence, you acknowledged his merits; but now that you have heard he is poor, you deſpiſe him. O! woman, woman!

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia
sp.p: (with heat). Sir, it is falſe. You injure me in every part of your opinion. When he was rich, he never knew that he had cauſed a tender thought in me; it was only his poverty that made my paſſion break out without diſguiſe. It was his diſtreſs that made me feel, and acknowledge I adore him.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: What, then, you do love him?

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia
sp.p: (much confuſed). What have I ſaid?

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: What you ought never to recal. Speak on; you now talk like a ſenſible woman.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: Well, then, receive my full confeſſion. You, his ſecond father! Mr. Aſgill has twined himſelf into my ſoul; his poverty has endeared him to me a thouſand times. Go, Sir, ſearch him out; bring him from his retreat, and tell him, that Horatia Horton knows no value in wealth, but in the pleaſure of dividing it with him.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Huzza, huzza! here's a woman for ye! Madam, he is not poor. I'll put down for Aſgill thouſand for thouſand, as long as you pleaſe, and when I die, leave him a plumb!

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p:
It was all a ſagacious trick of
mine. I wanted to try if the dear lad really loved me, and if he poſſeſſed real worth of ſoul. Sentiments, truly noble, he often uttered; but noble ſentiments are uttered by ſcoundrels, who do not poſſeſs one feeling, which, if brought to the touchſtone, would not diſgrace humanity.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: Mr. Aſgill not poor! (pauſing.) Nay, then I underſtand the flimſy contrivance. A pitiful plot, to force me to reveal a ſecret, which I choſe to bury in the bottom of my heart. Preſuming! (haughtily.) Make me a dupe! Now, Sir, know that your nephew rich, and your nephew poor, are two diſtinct perſons. I deteſt his art, and recal all I have ſaid. The rich Mr. Aſgill, I ſhall teach myſelf henceforward to deſpiſe. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Whu! Why, what's in the wind now? Upon my ſoul, I would rather caſt up the moſt intricate account of compound intereſt, than attempt to calculate what will pleaſe a woman. Refuſe a man becauſe he is rich!!!

sp.speaker: Perkins.
sp.p: O, Sir! I followed you here without your permiſſion, my tidings are ſo good, Mr. Aſgill is found.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Ah, Perkins, I ſaw it in thy eyes, without a word. Thou art an honeſt fellow, Perkins (ſqueezing his hand). In what ſtreet or alley was he found?

sp.speaker: Perkins.
sp.p:
Street, Sir! A very wide, and a very turbulent ſtreet. You will be ſurpriſed to hear. I employed my own brother in the buſineſs. He traced him laſt night down to
Portſmouth, where he had entered himſelf on board a man of war before the maſt!

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Perkins.
sp.p: Nay, come, Sir, he is returned.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Is he come back?

sp.speaker: Perkins.
sp.p: William prevailed on him; put him into a chaiſe and four, and brought him back to his own lodgings.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Come along, come along! It ſhall be the beſt day William ever ſaw. Exit.

div.head: SCENE—FANCOURT's.
div.stage: Enter FANCOURT, followed by Mrs. FANCOURT.

sp.speaker: Fancourt
sp.p: (careleſsly). Yes—no, my dear— yes—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: I hope you have been well amuſed ſince yeſterday, Mr. Fancourt?

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Perfectly ſo, Mrs. Fancourt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: You ſhou'd let me know when you do not mean to return. It is rather unpleaſant to ſit up all night watching.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: O! you can find amuſement.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: You are fond of maſquerading, you know.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: I do not underſtand you; I never was at more than one maſquerade, nor ever formed a wiſh to repeat it.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: And the habit you then wore, I remember, was that of a Savoyard.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt
sp.p: (ſtarting). It was.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: And did you then tell fortunes too?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt
sp.p: (aſide). I die with fear. Surely I am betrayed.

sp.speaker: Fancourt
sp.p: (ſeizing her hand), Come, tell me, Madam, have you not lately repeated the ſcene of the Savoyard?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Sir! O! he will have no mercy on me! (trembling.)

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: But, why need I aſk? I know you have. That fortune-telling was a pretty thought, my dear; but did it occur to you to tell your own fortune? Did you foretel to yourſelf your own fate on the diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Alas! I know too well I muſt expect all that malice and revenge can inſpire; but if I have ſaved an innocent from deſtruction, and turned away the arrow which was about to pierce the heart of her benevolent father, I am reſigned.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Who are you, who enter with ſo little ceremony into my apartments?

sp.speaker: 1ſt Man.
sp.p: What, Maſter Fancourt, don't you remember us? Mayhap you'll know this? (taking a conſtable's ſtaff from his pocket.)

sp.speaker: 2d Man,
sp.p: And this? (drawing forth another.)

sp.speaker: 1ſt Man.
sp.p: Here is a coach waiting below with two of our companions; ſo the quicker you are, the better.

sp.speaker: Fancourt
sp.p: (pale and trembling). This ſudden ſurpriſe has overpowered me. On whoſe account do I ſee you?

sp.speaker: 1ſt Man.
sp.p: You'll know that in proper time. I never likes to anſwer trogatories.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Where am I going?

sp.speaker: 2d Man.
sp.p: You'll ſee when we arrive.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Wherever it is, I will not ſtir without this woman. She ſhall accompany me wherever I go.

sp.speaker: 2d Man.
sp.p: Why, you have a very fond huſband, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Not ſo; but he is my huſband: I therefore follow without a murmur.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Go firſt; I will not leave you in the room? Exit Mrs. Fancourt. Come, gentlemen, let us follow the lady. Bear witneſs that I am a polite huſband to the laſt. Exit.

div.head: SCENE—Sir ROBERT's Drawing-room.
div.stage: He enters with a troubled air.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p:
A ſad, ſad ſlut! Why, what a town this is! A ſtranger, like me, ſhould go about in leading-ſtrings. Plotters, deceivers in every corner of it. Whether the people one aſſociates with, are what they appear to be, or whether it may not be all one univerſal maſquerade, there is no gueſſing. (Goes and opens the door.) Come—come forth! JENNY comes out, and walks to the front. He looks at her earneſtly.
Now art thou a woman, or a griffin, prithee tell me?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p:
Dear Sir, I can tell you no more than I have; I have confeſs'd every thing; and, on
my bended knees, I aſk for mercy. (kneeling) I am not a griffin, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Get up; your flummery of kneeling has no effect. How far I ſhall have mercy on a wretch, who plann'd the diſhonour of my child, I ſhall conſider. I have never met with ſo atrocious a jade, ſince the year I was high ſheriff for the county. Retire. Your brother, my Lord Beechgrove, approaches.

sp.speaker: Jenny
sp.p: (ſtarting up). I care not that for your ſneers! (ſnapping her fingers.) I'll teach you, my old gentleman, what it is for ſixty to have the impudence to ſlight five and twenty. I have waſted as many tender bluſhes, ſoft ogles, and enamoured glances on your ſhrivell'd chops, as might have fubdued half the gallant ſoldiers in the allied armies; but I'll be up with you yet!

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p:
O, a huſſy! What a ſad thing it is for a young man, like me, to have wanted gallantry. TIPPY enters.
My Lord, I am your lordſhip's moſt obedient. Why, you have made great haſte in undreſſing, my lord; you are a quick hand at a toilette, I ſee.

sp.speaker: Tippy
sp.p: (looking aghaſt). Hey!

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: I did not exactly know, at firſt, how to direct to you, to ſummon your lordſhip hither, but your ſiſter, the lady Jenny, help'd me out—Mr. Tippy!

sp.speaker: Tippy
sp.p: (aſide). The devil!

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p:
Pray, when do you publiſh, Sir?
Your life muſt be an amuſing one. Put me down as a ſubſcriber.

sp.speaker: Tippy
sp.p: (aſide). Nay, ſince all is out, I'll brazen it. I'll put you down for ſomething elſe, Sir, when I publiſh.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Aye.

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Be aſſured the public ſhall not want the ſtory of Taffy, the Welch knight; who came up a wool-gathering from Glamorganſhire, after Begums, Nanſooks, and Patna-rice.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Well, well, I feel that I deſerve this, ſo I take it patiently. Here comes more company; ſome of your friends, my lord.

div.stage: FANCOURT enters, Mrs. FANCOURT, and Conſtables. Sir ROBERT nods to the Conſtables, who retire.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: So, Tippy—all is up!

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Faith, I think, all is down—we have rather a tumble.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Be it ſo! I have aim'd high; reſolved if I did fall, to fall from an eminence. Well, Sir Knight, you'll give us a bottle of Champaigne at parting, and let us be merry once again! You thought it celeſtial happineſs, laſt night, to get tipſey with a lord, and hear him roar out an indecent catch. Do you remember, Tippy, how he oped his mouth, and how his eyes water'd with joy? Ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: I can bear all this, for I really have been ſo prepoſterouſly ridiculous, that, I think, I deſerve even more than your malice can ſuggeſt.

sp.speaker: Fancourt,
sp.p:
"I ſay, SNAPPER, we muſt have him on our ſide." Ha, ha, ha! "The old
ſcoundrel had like to have undone us (ſips). He is a great fool, but he is related to all the ap Morgans, and ap Shoneſes in the county." Ha, ha, ha! That was well, I never hook'd a gudgeon with ſo little trouble in my life!
It is, it is herſelf! My charming Savoyard, how I rejoice to ſee you! You are my mother, ſiſter, friend—

sp.speaker: Fancourt
sp.p: (going up to Mrs. Fancourt). You, Madam, to whoſe officiouſneſs my friend and I, owe our diſgrace—you ſhall be rewarded. Now liſten (ſeizing her hand), for I am going to plunge a dagger into your heart—you are not my wife. (flinging away her hand.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Not your wife?

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: No. Your affectation and delicacy would not permit you to be married in a Church, you may remember, ſo I took advantage of your folly, and brought a man, who was never prieſt till that moment.

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: It is very true, and I am he; it was I who married you. (bowing low)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Can it be poſſible? Do I hear right? Am I releas'd from obedience to a man whom I abhor? Is it no longer my duty to aſſociate with vice? Is it no longer my fate to eat the bread of wickedneſs? O, bliſsful moment!

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: I am ſurpriſed you feel ſo; he is a very good kind of young man.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: O! welcome poverty and want!

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p:
Never! Your fate is united to
mine. You are my mother, ſiſter, friend! I muſt quit you a few moments, for Lady Horatia Horton has ſent Mr. Conway for me; but I will leave you in my own apartment. My father's roof is your everlaſting protection!

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: This is, indeed, a ſtroke! Is ſhe to be happy?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Yes, that ſhe ſhall, if my protection can make her ſo.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Unhappy man, farewell! The ruin of my peace and fortune I can forgive! O! whilſt innocence and friendſhip invite me to repoſe, may you find it in repentance.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: And now, gentlemen, leave my houſe this moment, or the next you ſhall be returned into the hands of the conſtables. Go! turn out upon the world!

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: We will turn out upon the world; ſo let the world beware! Come, Tippy, the field before us is a wide one—let us erect our banners! Talents are our armed forces, with which we encounter Vanity and Foll. Where-ever they appear, we wage war. Allons! (to Tippy.) Be of good heart, my boy! The foe is numerous, but weak. Conqueſt and pillage are our own! They go off.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert
sp.p: (looking after them). I am glad you are off! Theſe gentlemen have given me ſome amuſement, together with ſome experience, and it has coſt me only one thouſand pounds —a cheap bargain! Exit.

div.head: SCENE—Lady HORATIA's Drawing-room.
div.stage: Lady HORATIA enters, accompanied by Lady CHARLOTTE.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: No—no—Adieu to low ſpirits for ever! My heart is as light as the feather in your hair; I know all; Mr. Conway has told me every thing; there was no plot on me! No, my Aſgill has proved himſelf in the hour of trial, as noble, as delicate, as brave as my fancy had always painted him.

sp.speaker: Lady Charlotte.
sp.p: Well, happineſs is a moſt becoming thing; it gives fire and expreſſion to every feature. But can it be poſſible that Mr. Aſgill ſhould deſign to ſerve as a ſailor? I thought the party with whom he—

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: Mention parties at an hour like this! O! let ſuch diſtinctions melt into air, and be obliterated for ever! Let every party join hand and heart to ſave this country, and to cheriſh its BLESSED CONSTITUTION!

sp.speaker: Lady Charlotte.
sp.p: See, here comes Georgina, playing the little tyrant with her enamour'd Conway.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: I proteſt I will not hear ſuch things, Mr. Conway. (ſnatches away her hand) Why will you teaze me thus? Lady Horatia, I beg you chide him; for he has been talking nonſenſe to me all the way in your coach.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p:
It will give him more pleaſure if you chide him. Nay, I will be more
malicious ſtill, ſpite of your frowns; I abſolutely will tell you— Georgina puts her hand to Lady Horatia's mouth. You do not hate him.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: O! that ſound is bliſs to me!

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Ah, but I am ſure I do not love him.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: How do you know, angel?

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Why, I never keep wakeful about you, nor ever dream about you. And I do not grow pale, like Miſs Gwatkin; and I eat my breakfaſt with pleaſure, and I dine very well; and if I do not ſee you for a whole day together, I only think—well, to-morrow I ſhall be more lucky.

sp.speaker: Conway
sp.p: (in rapture). Enough, enough— more than I hoped. On theſe terms I am content to bind my fate to yours. Such artleſs candour renders you enchanting.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Well, then—but do not ſpeak to my papa about it for whole week. Bleſs me— here's old Simon. (runs to the top, followed by Conway.)

div.stage: Enter Sir SIMON, with ASGILL, in a ſailor's dreſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Here, Madam, I have brought ye your ſailor; and if you do not receive him with kindneſs, and welcome him back with your whole ſoul, you are no woman for me!

sp.speaker: Aſgill
sp.p: (ruſhing to her feet). Adored miſtreſs of my heart! am I welcome?

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p:
Welcome! O, Aſgill, there are characters ſo high, ſo noble, that to be chained in by common decorums, would be to have no taſte for excellence, and my heart
bounds with diſdain from ſuch frozen rules! I, who have hitherto treated you with coldneſs, almoſt bordering on diſdain, now declare, in the preſence of my friends, that I am proud to make you maſter of my fate; that I feel exalted in having it in my power to confer happineſs on you.

sp.speaker: Aſgill
sp.p: (riſing). O! woman unequall'd!— Bleſſed be the hour in which you believed me poor and undone! Sir Simon has been feeding my ſoul with exſtacy.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: Mr. Aſgill, you muſt, indeed, love Sir Simon; but I know not how I ſhall ſet about doing ſo; he hates the arts; he thinks there is nothing dignified in ſculpture; he hears, without veneration, the names of Phidias, and Michael Angelo.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Come, come, Madam, throw away your chiſel and your marble blocks, and ſet about making a good wife. That ART is the nobleſt pride of an Engliſhwoman.

sp.speaker: Lady Charlotte.
sp.p: Lady Horatia, you are all ſmiles! I declare I ſhould not ſo eaſily have forgiven a man (looking on Aſgill) who could fly from me to the boiſterous ocean, and prove ſuch inſenſibility to beauty and love.

sp.speaker: Aſgill.
sp.p:
Misjudge me not! I, inſenſible to beauty, and to love! O! my glowing ſoul confeſſes their force, and adores their power. Yet the enthuſiaſm which ſeized me, when I trod the deck of the Victory, can never be chill'd! In the glorious tars around me, valour, intrepidity, heroiſm, ſhone forth with all their fires; they flaſhed through my heart! And, I ſwear, that ſhould my country need my aſſiſtance, I will again reſume the trowſers,
and ſail before the maſt, wherever ſhe bids her cannon roar, or her proud pendants fly. (Advancing forward) Ah! repoſe on us! And when you look on the gallant ſpirits, who do honour to this habit, let every fear ſubſide; for, whilſt the ſea flows, and Engliſh ſailors are themſelves, ENGLAND MUST BE THE MISTRESS OF THE GLOBE!

div.head: EPILOGUE, MISS WALLIS.
div.l: THROUGH five long Acts—a pretty decent ſwing—
I've been a giddy, tender, harmleſs thing;
Light as a feather, in the morn of May,
Borne by the perfum'd breath of blue-eyed day.
Nor have I yet thrown by my ſtudied part,
GEORGINA, ſtill I am, in garb, and heart—
GEORGINA humbly ſtands again before ye,
Of gratitude ſo full!—ſhe half adores ye.
It puzzles me to gueſs, when Conway's wife,
On what ſweet plan to form my married life:
My heart beats high to think how I ſhall flaſh,
Pre-eminent, and bold, like Lady Daſh.
Reflection ne'er to me ſhall be a damper,
My curricle I'll drive—on horſeback ſcamper—
Keep Pharo Banks—take the long odds at races,
And know the knowing ones, in all their paces;
Lounge at Newmarket in the betting-rooms,
And prate to Lady Harriet—and my grooms.
But whilſt I thus blaze on, in Folly's road,
And profligate, forſake my bleſt abode—
Where is my huſband's peace?—his honour—where?
Who ſhall his lonely hours conſole, and ſhare?
O! the black proſpect ſcares my trembling art,
And from the headlong precipice I ſtart.
Dear wedded happineſs! my ſoul is thine,
My pride ſhall be, in thy mild paths to ſhine—
My CONWAY's temperate joys I'll make my own,
And his felicity my life ſhall crown;
With him through Pleaſure's paths I'll ſometimes roam,
But ſtill my firſt enjoyment, ſhall be HOME.
The Houſehold Gods ten thouſand graces wear.
Nor ſtoop to borrow tinſel'd, foreign glare—
Yet never ſhall your Houſehold Deities frown,
Though you ſhould ſteal an hour, to ſee—THE TOWN!
